title: How SMBs Can Free Up 35% of Owner Time Using AI Agents | Len Landale, Helios Core AI

rawLines.text:
Len, welcome to Just Curious.
 Thanks, D.

Appreciate you having us on.
 You have
decades of enterprise IT and cloud
experience. What led you to start Helios
Core and why now?
Yeah, it's uh it's been a long time in
the managed services and managed
application world for me and the
inflection point was kind of twofold.
one from a personal perspective being in
a large corporation and some of the
inflexible and slowmoving elements of a
company like that as well as the more
inward focus versus outward
entrepreneurial focus kind of gotten to
a point where I uh really needed to
change personally and then when when
looking at what to do in today's climate
and market AI was you know clearly
clearly a hot topic but our approach was
a little bit different in starting a
platform focused AI AI managed services
business. So coupling platform and
managed services together to really help
businesses solve their problems. Um and
I think that's a little bit unique still
in what we're seeing in the market

today.
 Can you tell us a little bit more
about Helios Core? You mentioned
platform plus managed services. Tell us
a little bit more about what Helios Core
does, where it's focused with respect to
AI, who it's focused on serving, and
then also what kind of value is enabled
through marrying the platform and
managed services.
Yeah. So, we're we're not focused on any
particular industry, but kind of broadly
across solving business problems for our
customers, right? That could be customer
service, that could be sales, that could
be internal um business processes, HR
and finance, small business up to maybe
the small enterprise type size of
company. I think the the big thing that
we're seeing is there's this kind of
there's everybody wants to do it, but
there's a there's a confusion as to
where to start, right? So one of the
offerings that we have and one of the
things we're helping a lot of companies
identify within their business is just
is just where they could apply AI, what
makes sense to use as a use case. So
there's definitely a training and
enablement element as well as use case
development to help them understand
where AI could be applied and then we
bring the platform and services to bear
on that particular problem. So, one of
the unique things about the Helios Core
platform that we've built is, you know,
it's it's it's kind of a springboard to
bring Agentic AI into into a business
and it allows for companies to leverage
that platform to do agents that take
calls or take emails or make tool calls
into their backend systems and and
things like that.
Why should small and middle market
companies care about AI?
I I think it's hugely important. I I I
mean, maybe it's just uh I've been in in
the AI world for the last 12 months and
I'm drinking the Kool-Aid, but I think
it's going to change the way that
everything operates. And if you're not
taking advantage or starting to take
advantage in your business today, then
someone else is going to bypass you. So,
I think it's hugely important for small
businesses or businesses of any size to
really start doing something in AI now.
even if it's small, even if it's just
taking personal tasks and seeing what
they can do to really use it as a force
multiplier. But I really think the the
value and where they're going to be able
to accelerate growth is in this agentic
AI space is where you know you can take
processes,
take an agent and apply knowledge from
your business and let it make decisions
and take action. That's where you can
free yourself up to do more value added
tasks. And especially in small
businesses, you know, there's so many

hats that people are wearing.
 If you
have to do everything, right, and you
have a small team that's supporting your
business, right, that's all the more
reason to go and try to apply this new
technology to how uh how you operate
your business.
We're going to walk through an example
of what that looks like, but maybe we
could start at the beginning by defining
a core concept. What is an AI agent in
your words? And how does it fit into the
world of traditional AI, generative AI,
and now agentic AI?
Yeah. So, let's I guess we can start at
the at the tail of that and walk back to
Agentic AI. I mean, generative AI um is
is really what kind of the the chat GTP
moment and this creative AI that's out
there now that really is caused a lot of
the the ground swell, right? So, those
are prompted, right? You interact with
them, you can have them do things for
you, but then it's done, right? They
don't they don't do anything past that.
Um, you know, traditional AI or or
machine learning, um, you know, that was
a lot more uh data science driven,
right? I'm going to give you a whole
bunch of data that's going to be very
wellmaintained and cleansed and and then
have you look at it through different
angles. Um the generative AI and now
agentic AI, you know, still needs data.
Data is key. Uh but it's maybe a little
bit less. It's or a little bit more
forgiving, right? It's a little bit less
about the data science and having these
these massive data projects and then
being able to give enough data that it
makes sense for the process to work, but
not having to to go down that road so
far. So the the agentic piece of it is
really taking the large language models
and and the generative AI that's that
kind of kick this all off and giving it
what I would say is is two major
qualities right one of them obviously
you need to give it business data so it
needs to have some knowledge needs to
have some knowledge of your business
process and what you're looking for it
to achieve so it has to have that
persona that framework right a large
language model and the and the backend
frontier models is critical to the
agents doing their their work but it's
got to know about your business. So,
it's got to have that. It's then going
to make some level of decision based off
of the inputs that it receives and the
knowledge of your business. So, that
that decision-m capability is is
critical to the agentic nature of it.
And then the last thing is really the
tool calling. It's got to be able to
take some action. It's not it's not
going to be as valuable if it just takes
the information about your business,
uses a large language model and all the
knowledge that it has of the world and
then makes a decision and then sits on
it. Right? then it's going to hand it
back to you and you're going to have to
do something with it. So that tool
calling, that ability to act is really
what makes it agentic. So then it can
scale. It can do things in your business
with some level of autonomy. You know,
obviously we always want to have a human
in the loop. We want to have some
accountability and ability to track what
the agents are doing and the decisions
they're they're making, the actions
they're taking. But that's where the
real value is in the Aentic AI is it's
going to work 24 by7, you know, 365 at
scale on your behalf. And that's where
where the the true value of the agentic

AI comes in.
 Yeah. What kind of tasks
and I think you spoke to a few earlier.
What kind of tasks can agents actually
do today? And what kind of information
do they need in order to work reliably
in a business setting?
So one of the one of the ones that we're
focused on is kind of a customer service
engagement, right? So I think that's a
good use case for Aentic AI. So having a
conversation either via chat or voice if
it's a calling scenario having that
conversation and then doing something
from a customer service perspective.
Maybe that's taking orders, maybe that's
answering questions, but then the action
is it's going to it's going to then put
that order in or it's going to think of
it in the in the context of a service
desk, right? it's going to have the
conversation, then it's going to reset
the password or it's going to mail you
the standard operating procedure for you
to go execute something on your laptop
or whatever the case may be. So, I think
the the the customer service use case is
a is a great one and it's fairly broad,
right, across all all businesses. You
could you could imagine how it could
work in yours. I think the outbound
engagement is also another interesting
use case where you could craft very
personalized messages to either your
customers thanking them your prospective
customers or even do some prospecting
with aentic AI and give that
personalization to it. So I think

there's lots of potential with it.
 Yeah,
there's a lot of activity in uh Aentic
AI. What's different about the Helios
core platform you're building?
Yeah, I think I think one of the things
that we're differentiating oursel with
is this idea of the platform delivered
managed services, right? So, a lot of
call it point-and-click tool-based
agentic platforms are out there is
really a software as a service that you
would go and buy a seat and then, you
know, try to create your own agents and
and those are going to be good for maybe
offloading some of your individual
personal tasks, but they're not going to
run business process at scale. So that's
what we want to do with our our platform
and services together. So we're not
selling the platform to the community.
We're trying to bring it as an enabler
to get those business outcomes achieved.
Um and we're also then going to continue
to engage in a managed service so that
the you know you're not left holding the
bag so to speak, right? especially, you
know, small businesses have a ton of
hats to wear, like like I talked about
before. And, you know, being able to
rely on a partner that's going to make
sure that the the deployment that you've
got is doing what you want it to do.
It's going to course correct if there's
something that's an issue. It's going to
allow you to give us feedback and maybe
add additional features into the the
system as it grows with your business.
So, I think that's a big differentiator.
I think, you know, it's a lot to ask a
small business to go out and learn this
technology. It's changing very quickly.
there's tons of different new products
coming into the market and what's going
to be right for their business is
difficult to kind of go choose. So the
point-and-click kind of SAS offerings I
think can help, you know, individuals
offload tasks for sure and do that in an
autonomous agentic way, which is great,
but they're not really going to take on
business functions and and accomplish
business goals in the same way that we
think we can with our our platform and

services.
 Yeah. Let's walk through an
example of that. Uh you mentioned to me
earlier uh work that you've been doing
with a rental services company. I'd love
to share that story, what problem they
came to you with and then how you went
about building them an agentic solution.
So, so who came to you and uh what was

the problem?
 Yeah, so it's a it's a
local rental business. The they rent
heavy equipment um you know, skid
steers, excavators, floor sanders, you
know, to a mix of construction companies
that are that are doing things as well
as the the general public. So, as you
might imagine, they get tons of
inquiries, right? inquiries around
availability, inquiries around pricing,
what they what they do and don't rent.
So, a lot of those calls are coming in
and distracting from the rest of the
business, right? Running running the
operations, dispatching equipment,
dealing with problems, fixing and
maintaining equipment. They run a
relatively small staff. So, the the
owner of the business has to field a lot
of those calls. And his challenge was
twofold. one, he he struggled to give
the same level of customer service and
the ability to try to solve customers
problems and and get them the
information in a very customer- ccentric
way by just taking someone off of their
post and having them answer the phones.
So, he always saw a a degrading quality
if he wasn't the one doing the job. And
he then had all of the other things he
needs to do in the business suffer
because he's always taking all the phone
calls, right? So his goal was quite
clearly just to reduce the number of
things he had to answer every day if it
was a price quote or if it was just an
answer. Do you have this if if it's
available? That was his main goal.
Therefore, he could free up his time to
deal more intimately with customers who
had problems to help his staff from
managing the the fleet of equipment and
uh and the rest of the business. So that
was the problem we set out to solve.
What we built was based off of our
framework. We we trained an agent to
know all of his pricing and all of his
pricing policies, right? So, he's got
some unique ways he prices and, you
know, very customer-friendly way to
extend a rental and things like that. As
well as delivery policies, you know, how
far, how much, etc. So, we had to ch
train our agent on all of those uh you
know, different elements of his
business. Um, and then it would take
phone calls for him, right? So, that's
that's what uh that's what it was
deployed to do. it's mainly going to
give pricing and take bookings. Um, but
he he sees the opportunity to expand
that to potentially, you know,
dispatching for dropping off equipment,
picking up equipment in the future and

additional benefits.
 Yeah. How do you
how do you train an agent like that? Um,
so what sorts of information does it
have to ingest to be able to simulate to
replicate the experience of talking to
the owner of a business? the owner of a
business who presumably has been doing
this for a long time and is an e expert
really in his business. How how do you
train that agent? What what what sort of
things do you feed it to give it um
confidence and information to respond to

questions?
 So probably one of the
biggest challenges was exactly that,
right? So we could get it 70% of the way
there just from data that he had, right?
He had he had data on his website. He
had, you know, his pricing policy was
clear. he had the price per, you know,
um piece of equipment per per duration
of rental. So, we could get a lot of
that to ingest it into um into answering
questions just based off of that data.
And it would give that coupled with the
knowledge that's in a large language
model, right? And of course, we had to
give it guardrail so it wasn't making
things up or finding something on the
internet and just answering the question
with something that wasn't true and
hallucinating. So, we had to narrow it
down based off of the data that we had
about his business as well as just what
the LLM can infer from knowledge, but
that only got it maybe 70% of the way
there. The other 30% was the real
difficult piece. And that'll be
iterative. Um, but that was extracting
all of the 20 plus years of knowledge,
right? And things he would just
intrinsically know and say on a call.
Um, because he is who he is and what
he's done for so long. and and the agent
would have no way of knowing that
because it's not written down and it's
just his way of working. Um, so that was
the biggest challenge because, you know,
he's a busy guy and having him call and
and test during testing and training to
give us feedback is is something he had
to free up his time to do. And then the
the way to get that information out,
it's not like it was a document he just
didn't give us, right? It was knowledge
and it was in his head. So, we actually
came up with a creative solution for
that. Whereas during training, he could
call and have a conversation like he was
a customer. But if the agent ever went
and did something he didn't want it to,
and you know, it answered a question the
way it didn't want he didn't want it to.
And we actually built in kind of like a
a keyword he could say, which would take
the agent out of I'm a rental agent
solving your problems into I'm just
listening now to how you want me to
behave. And that would give that would
give him the ability to dictate to it
what exactly he would say. Right? Right?
So now this is how I would handle the
solution or the situation in in uh in
that scenario. And then we would get
that notes and our development team
could incorporate that back into the
behavior. Maybe that was changing the
prompt, right? Maybe it was, you know,
we were getting pricing wrong or uh it
had read into something from the data
and that that happened a few times like
uh you know, he doesn't rent painting
equipment, doesn't rent paint sprayers
or any of those things, but one of the
descriptions of a different piece of
equipment, I think it was a pressure
washer, had something that confused the
agent, right? So, he started asking
questions and, you know, kind of broke
in and said, "Wait a minute, I don't
rent this stuff. How are you getting
that?" So we had to figure out from what
the model was responding with from our
our our rag database as to what it was
getting and why it thought that it
rented something it didn't. And that
allowed us to kind of correct the
behavior and get back on on track. So
that was a bit of an innovative thing
that we built into the process for him
in order to make it easy for him to to
help us train.
How does this integrate into his
existing business and um the stack?
Yeah. So, a little bit of challenges
around that just because the software
that he was on from a call it a back-end
product doesn't expose a lot. So, we
originally just gave him a very clean
way to then take the the rental
information that the c the customer
wanted and input it. That was the first
kind of phase. The second phase is to
integrate with QuickBooks for him
because that's what he uses in the
background and they've got a more robust
API. Uh so, we're going to leverage that
for a lot of the things that we can then
pull from an inventory perspective and
data and customer information. So that's
where we're pulling customer information
and um updating customer information.
We're leveraging QuickBooks from that
perspective because his other tool
didn't have it and he already has a

synchronization between those two.
 Yeah.
Was there any skepticism on his part
about the potential for AI and agents to
um kind of replicate him before you
began and like how how does he feel
about it now?
Yeah, there's definitely some skepticism
because he's he's again he's a very
vibrant individual, right? He's always
he's outgoing. He's very engaging,
right? So, he he wanted to really have a
digital twin of himself and we didn't
set out to digitize his personality,
right? What we what we wanted to do was
create something that could offload the
work and do it in a very professional
way and not sound, you know, like a
robot to attend customers. So the the
voice that we chose right from an
engagement perspective was part of that
the speed with which it talks and some
of the the the ways it is engag is in
some of that. So he was a bit skeptical
at first partly because you know he is
who he is from a personality perspective
but also we just we had to temper that a
little bit and say like that we're not
trying to recreate you from a
personality perspective. We're trying to
recreate what you're doing in your
business. Um so we set expectations a
little bit from that perspective. Uh,
and then once we got the first kind of
MVP up and he could have a bit of a
conversation, just ask questions about
equipment, um, he was actually
pleasantly surprised because it's just
knowledgeable knowledgeable about what
he has and um, what it could be used for
and and whatnot. Um, and then we had to
iterate and fine-tune on the various
permutations and combinations of
equipment, right, to to make it feel
more like he would naturally engage. But
once we got it to that level, I think uh
you know, it got him to a point where he
was confident it could at least engage
uh and and take a a good portion of of
calls and answer, you know, a lot of
questions that people had. Of course, we
still need to give the customers a way
that they can escalate. He can talk to
them individually and answer questions
if if the agent can't get it. And we
anticipate that also improving over
time, right? Give it a year worth of
training and and back and forth and
it'll be better than it is on launch.
Yeah. And my understanding this is
recently deployed. So not all the
numbers are in, but previously he was
spending all his time doing customer
service related calls. What does the
kind of after state look like in terms

of what his week is like now?
 Yeah,
you're you're right. We're we're early
days. Um it's kind of a phased roll out.
So it's not it's not being asked to take
100% of his workload in the beginning
here. So before any deployment, he was
yeah on the phone all the time. probably
70% of his day was on the phone either
answering questions or taking new
bookings or dealing with an issue of of
a rental. So the out of the gate numbers
were we're anticipating tracking that
towards 50% of his calls which mainly is
going to be the bookings and pricing
inquiries and do you rent this equipment
or that equipment. We fully anticipate
that he's still going to handle customer
issues where they've had a problem, the
machine can't start, they had an
accident, right? those types of
scenarios, we fully anticipate him still
engaging and that's where he's going to
spend his time on the phone. But those
lowhanging fruit from a from a customer
inquiry or booking, we anticipate taking
those calls. So, probably about half of

his total calls.
 Yeah. And 70% of his
time was on call. So, you're talking
about potentially freeing up 35% of his

time.
 Yep.
And tell me a little bit about the role
of the managed service part of the
business here. um what what what what
are you doing with him on an ongoing
basis to ensure this works and scales

and delivers that value?
 Yeah. So, as
part of the ongoing service, so first of
all, we give him visibility into what's
going on. So, we have a a portal that
has access into view all the calls. It
analyzes sentiment of the call. So, he
he can flag up if there was a call that
was a negative sentiment. you can follow
up with the customer if need be or he
can listen to the call or read the
transcript and then give us feedback and
say, "Hey, this is this is behavior we
need to correct." So the service is
really to provide him the visibility
into what's going on and then work with
him to correct anything where the
behavior isn't what he wants. So then he
gets the product that he wants long
term, right? In addition to that kind of
visibility and ability to see what the
agent's doing, that human oversight, we
also have some effort for him to tune
it. So, for example, you know,
dispatching is something he he thinks it
might do in the future. Well, if if that
dispatch is as simple as saying, "Hey,
this order is in and we can read his
backend financial system and it's due
out tomorrow, right? At the end of the
day, the agent could go through all of
the things that are due to be delivered
tomorrow and it could go and and make a
phone call or a text message to the
drivers to go and say, "Hey, here's your
your schedule for the day." So building
those additional functionalities in over
time is another element of the the
managed service too. So it's going to
continue to grow and add value to his

business.
 And this was a voice agent.
Tell me a little bit more about voice
agents and why is voice such an
important domain for AI right now.
Yeah, I think I think voice is one of
the things that we've you know we think
we've built a really good product around
and we're a little bit surprised to see
how quickly that part of the industry's
taken off. There's there's tons of new
development coming out from Frontier
Models and and other companies that are
focused on making voice better, you
know, and and that's great because we
can take advantage of that, right? Our
platform is going to be able to take
advantage of new technology under the
hood to to make it better in the future.
So, that's fantastic for us. We welcome
that. So, I think the advancements that
are coming in in the voice space and the
um ability to expand that into other
areas like I mentioned marketing
earlier, right? outbound marketing could
be an area you could expand voice into.
So, we're excited about all all that
that's going on. I think the other thing
that's interesting from a voice
perspective is, you know, the way that
the way that people work is going to
change. I think it already is, right?
You see uh large investments in in
different modes of of technology like
glasses, right? Instead of sitting at a
computer and typing and moving a mouse
like we've done for decades, right? um
you know, mobile and dictation of things
to your phone and having glasses that
could recognize the environment and then
interact with you through voice and
having that backed up by a large
language model and a voice agent. You
know, all of those things coming
together uh I think is where the the
future of voice is going. I think that's
kind of exciting.
Yeah. Uh this example is for rental
services company. What other types of
companies or industries could this type
of solution be valuable for? Also,
I mean, I think the voice agent, think
about what this this is doing is really
order taking. So, any type of
interaction where you've got a product
catalog and pricing and your customers
call in or potentially just want to have
a more robust conversation with you over
an agent on your website that can
actually take action. I think this is
applicable. Right? So that's a pretty
wide swap just in what we've already got
um that we've talked about today. Right?
Uh the the other thing though that I
think is interesting about the platform
and where Agentic AI is going is um you
know it's it's adaptable to many
different business processes. So we're
we're looking at um like a sales
coaching agent. Again, it's going to
ingest voice. It's going to ingest calls
from sales calls. Uh, it's going to give
feedback on products that they could
offer as part of the customer's needs.
It's going to analyze what they're doing
for their customers today and and where
they could fill the need of their
customers in the future. It's going to
help them do research on new people
they're meeting in order to see what
their priorities might might mean or
might be. So, you know, there's a
there's that compostability, that
expandability of the platform, I think
is pretty exciting, too. So, you know,
anything from a and that's not really
just voice, that's voice, that's text,
that's, you know, just regular search,
all that coming together in in another

agentic in aentic way.
 Yeah. Very cool.
As we come to a close, um would love
your advice for SMB leaders. So, what's
a piece of advice for a leader who's
skeptical about whether there are
opportunities within his or her business
to use AI?
Yeah, I I think for an SMB leader who's
maybe hesitant, I think educating
yourself on what's going on a little
bit. I mean, obviously I'm deep in the
weeds every day in this space. Um, and
and it's impossible for someone who's
running a business to get that deep into
it that's not doing it for their
business. But take the time. Take the
time to educate yourself. Start using
it. even if it's just, you know, asking
questions about what your industry is
doing or trends or how how you could
look at a problem a different way. I
think once once people start interacting
with AI in a in a general sense and
thinking about it in their business, the
light bulbs will start to go off and and
then they'll investigate further. And
then I think once they get to that
point, having conversations with

companies like ours,
 right? To just talk
about the art of the possible is is a
really good way to explore what
potentially you could do, right? Doesn't
cost you anything to have a conversation
with a company and say, "Hey, what do
you do and how would it work in my
business?" But I think once once the
light bulb goes off and they see the
potential, that's, you know, that's
going to be it's going to be a phase
shift for their business. And I don't I
don't want to sound like fear-mongering
or or anything else, but I also do
firmly believe that if you're burying
your head in the sand right now, like if
you're just like it's not applicable, I
run a small business. It's chat's bit
just for big enterprise. Why would I
bother? Or it's not real. It's all hype,
right? I think that's probably the worst
decision, right? Because I I do firmly
believe that it's going to change, you
know, the way people work, the way
businesses are built, right? the way
that your competition is operating. So,
if you just choose to ignore it, you you
truly do run the risk that someone's
just going to just bypass you, right?
Either a new company that's starting up
in your space that's going to embrace it
from the ground or one of your
competitors that's that's taking
advantage to educate themselves and
reaching out to companies and having
conversations and looking for use cases,
right? I mean, if you're going to hire
one new person, maybe take that
investment and do something in the AI
space. see if that can return more than
what one new person would do in your
organization. Right. So, I think just
just getting started is the most

critical thing.
 Yeah. Awesome. What a
good place to end. Len, I really
appreciate you coming by just curious
and sharing more about what you're doing
with Helios Core and how you're helping
small businesses use this technology to
better navigate the future. Thank you.
Thanks, D. Really appreciate it. Can't
wait to uh talk to you about more use
cases in the future.

cleanText:
Len, welcome to Just Curious.
Thanks, D.
Appreciate you having us on.
You have decades of enterprise IT and cloud experience. What led you to start Helios Core and why now?
Yeah, it's uh it's been a long time in the managed services and managed application world for me and the inflection point was kind of twofold. One from a personal perspective being in a large corporation and some of the inflexible and slow-moving elements of a company like that as well as the more inward focus versus outward entrepreneurial focus kind of gotten to a point where I uh really needed to change personally and then when when looking at what to do in today's climate and market AI was you know clearly clearly a hot topic but our approach was a little bit different in starting a platform focused AI AI managed services business. So coupling platform and managed services together to really help businesses solve their problems. Um and I think that's a little bit unique still in what we're seeing in the market today.
Can you tell us a little bit more about Helios Core? You mentioned platform plus managed services. Tell us a little bit more about what Helios Core does, where it's focused with respect to AI, who it's focused on serving, and then also what kind of value is enabled through marrying the platform and managed services.
Yeah. So, we're we're not focused on any particular industry, but kind of broadly across solving business problems for our customers, right? That could be customer service, that could be sales, that could be internal um business processes, HR and finance, small business up to maybe the small enterprise type size of company. I think the the big thing that we're seeing is there's this kind of there's everybody wants to do it, but there's a there's a confusion as to where to start, right? So one of the offerings that we have and one of the things we're helping a lot of companies identify within their business is just is just where they could apply AI, what makes sense to use as a use case. So there's definitely a training and enablement element as well as use case development to help them understand where AI could be applied and then we bring the platform and services to bear on that particular problem. So, one of the unique things about the Helios Core platform that we've built is, you know, it's it's it's kind of a springboard to bring Agentic AI into into a business and it allows for companies to leverage that platform to do agents that take calls or take emails or make tool calls into their backend systems and and things like that.
Why should small and middle market companies care about AI?
I I think it's hugely important. I I I mean, maybe it's just uh I've been in in the AI world for the last 12 months and I'm drinking the Kool-Aid, but I think it's going to change the way that everything operates. And if you're not taking advantage or starting to take advantage in your business today, then someone else is going to bypass you. So, I think it's hugely important for small businesses or businesses of any size to really start doing something in AI now. Even if it's small, even if it's just taking personal tasks and seeing what they can do to really use it as a force multiplier. But I really think the the value and where they're going to be able to accelerate growth is in this agentic AI space is where you know you can take processes, take an agent and apply knowledge from your business and let it make decisions and take action. That's where you can free yourself up to do more value added tasks. And especially in small businesses, you know, there's so many hats that people are wearing.
If you have to do everything, right, and you have a small team that's supporting your business, right, that's all the more reason to go and try to apply this new technology to how uh how you operate your business.
We're going to walk through an example of what that looks like, but maybe we could start at the beginning by defining a core concept. What is an AI agent in your words? And how does it fit into the world of traditional AI, generative AI, and now agentic AI?
Yeah. So, let's I guess we can start at the at the tail of that and walk back to Agentic AI. I mean, generative AI um is is really what kind of the the chat GTP moment and this creative AI that's out there now that really is caused a lot of the the ground swell, right? So, those are prompted, right? You interact with them, you can have them do things for you, but then it's done, right? They don't they don't do anything past that. Um, you know, traditional AI or or machine learning, um, you know, that was a lot more uh data science driven, right? I'm going to give you a whole bunch of data that's going to be very well-maintained and cleansed and and then have you look at it through different angles. Um the generative AI and now agentic AI, you know, still needs data. Data is key. Uh but it's maybe a little bit less. It's or a little bit more forgiving, right? It's a little bit less about the data science and having these these massive data projects and then being able to give enough data that it makes sense for the process to work, but not having to to go down that road so far. So the the agentic piece of it is really taking the large language models and and the generative AI that's that kind of kick this all off and giving it what I would say is is two major qualities right one of them obviously you need to give it business data so it needs to have some knowledge needs to have some knowledge of your business process and what you're looking for it to achieve so it has to have that persona that framework right a large language model and the and the backend frontier models is critical to the agents doing their their work but it's got to know about your business. So, it's got to have that. It's then going to make some level of decision based off of the inputs that it receives and the knowledge of your business. So, that that decision-making capability is is critical to the agentic nature of it. And then the last thing is really the tool calling. It's got to be able to take some action. It's not it's not going to be as valuable if it just takes the information about your business, uses a large language model and all the knowledge that it has of the world and then makes a decision and then sits on it. Right? then it's going to hand it back to you and you're going to have to do something with it. So that tool calling, that ability to act is really what makes it agentic. So then it can scale. It can do things in your business with some level of autonomy. You know, obviously we always want to have a human in the loop. We want to have some accountability and ability to track what the agents are doing and the decisions they're they're making, the actions they're taking. But that's where the real value is in the agentic AI is it's going to work 24 by7, you know, 365 at scale on your behalf. And that's where where the the true value of the agentic AI comes in.
Yeah. What kind of tasks and I think you spoke to a few earlier. What kind of tasks can agents actually do today? And what kind of information do they need in order to work reliably in a business setting?
So one of the one of the ones that we're focused on is kind of a customer service engagement, right? So I think that's a good use case for agentic AI. So having a conversation either via chat or voice if it's a calling scenario having that conversation and then doing something from a customer service perspective. Maybe that's taking orders, maybe that's answering questions, but then the action is it's going to it's going to then put that order in or it's going to think of it in the in the context of a service desk, right? it's going to have the conversation, then it's going to reset the password or it's going to mail you the standard operating procedure for you to go execute something on your laptop or whatever the case may be. So, I think the the the customer service use case is a is a great one and it's fairly broad, right, across all all businesses. You could you could imagine how it could work in yours. I think the outbound engagement is also another interesting use case where you could craft very personalized messages to either your customers thanking them your prospective customers or even do some prospecting with agentic AI and give that personalization to it. So I think there's lots of potential with it.
Yeah, there's a lot of activity in uh agentic AI. What's different about the Helios Core platform you're building?
Yeah, I think I think one of the things that we're differentiating oursel with is this idea of the platform delivered managed services, right? So, a lot of call it point-and-click tool-based agentic platforms are out there is really a software as a service that you would go and buy a seat and then, you know, try to create your own agents and and those are going to be good for maybe offloading some of your individual personal tasks, but they're not going to run business process at scale. So that's what we want to do with our our platform and services together. So we're not selling the platform to the community. We're trying to bring it as an enabler to get those business outcomes achieved. Um and we're also then going to continue to engage in a managed service so that the you know you're not left holding the bag so to speak, right? Especially, you know, small businesses have a ton of hats to wear, like like I talked about before. And, you know, being able to rely on a partner that's going to make sure that the the deployment that you've got is doing what you want it to do. It's going to course correct if there's something that's an issue. It's going to allow you to give us feedback and maybe add additional features into the the system as it grows with your business. So, I think that's a big differentiator. I think, you know, it's a lot to ask a small business to go out and learn this technology. It's changing very quickly. there's tons of different new products coming into the market and what's going to be right for their business is difficult to kind of go choose. So the point-and-click kind of SAS offerings I think can help, you know, individuals offload tasks for sure and do that in an autonomous agentic way, which is great, but they're not really going to take on business functions and and accomplish business goals in the same way that we think we can with our our platform and services.
Yeah. Let's walk through an example of that. Uh you mentioned to me earlier uh work that you've been doing with a rental services company. I'd love to share that story, what problem they came to you with and then how you went about building them an agentic solution.
So, so who came to you and uh what was the problem?
Yeah, so it's a it's a local rental business. The they rent heavy equipment um you know, skid steers, excavators, floor sanders, you know, to a mix of construction companies that are that are doing things as well as the the general public. So, as you might imagine, they get tons of inquiries, right? Inquiries around availability, inquiries around pricing, what they what they do and don't rent. So, a lot of those calls are coming in and distracting from the rest of the business, right? Running running the operations, dispatching equipment, dealing with problems, fixing and maintaining equipment. They run a relatively small staff. So, the the owner of the business has to field a lot of those calls. And his challenge was twofold. one, he he struggled to give the same level of customer service and the ability to try to solve customers problems and and get them the information in a very customer-centric way by just taking someone off of their post and having them answer the phones. So, he always saw a a degrading quality if he wasn't the one doing the job. And he then had all of the other things he needs to do in the business suffer because he's always taking all the phone calls, right? So his goal was quite clearly just to reduce the number of things he had to answer every day if it was a price quote or if it was just an answer. Do you have this if if it's available? That was his main goal. Therefore, he could free up his time to deal more intimately with customers who had problems to help his staff from managing the the fleet of equipment and uh and the rest of the business. So that was the problem we set out to solve. What we built was based off of our framework. We we trained an agent to know all of his pricing and all of his pricing policies, right? So, he's got some unique ways he prices and, you know, very customer-friendly way to extend a rental and things like that. As well as delivery policies, you know, how far, how much, etc. So, we had to train our agent on all of those uh you know, different elements of his business. Um, and then it would take phone calls for him, right? So, that's that's what uh that's what it was deployed to do. it's mainly going to give pricing and take bookings. Um, but he he sees the opportunity to expand that to potentially, you know, dispatching for dropping off equipment, picking up equipment in the future and additional benefits.
Yeah. How do you how do you train an agent like that? Um, so what sorts of information does it have to ingest to be able to simulate to replicate the experience of talking to the owner of a business? the owner of a business who presumably has been doing this for a long time and is an expert really in his business. How how do you train that agent? What what what sort of things do you feed it to give it um confidence and information to respond to questions?
So probably one of the biggest challenges was exactly that, right? So we could get it 70% of the way there just from data that he had, right? He had he had data on his website. He had, you know, his pricing policy was clear. he had the price per, you know, um piece of equipment per per duration of rental. So, we could get a lot of that to ingest it into um into answering questions just based off of that data. And it would give that coupled with the knowledge that's in a large language model, right? And of course, we had to give it guardrails so it wasn't making things up or finding something on the internet and just answering the question with something that wasn't true and hallucinating. So, we had to narrow it down based off of the data that we had about his business as well as just what the LLM can infer from knowledge, but that only got it maybe 70% of the way there. The other 30% was the real difficult piece. And that'll be iterative. Um, but that was extracting all of the 20 plus

years of knowledge, right? And things he would just intrinsically know and say on a call. Um, because he is who he is and what he's done for so long. And the agent would have no way of knowing that because it's not written down and it's just his way of working. Um, so that was the biggest challenge because, you know, he's a busy guy and having him call and and test during testing and training to give us feedback is is something he had to free up his time to do. And then the the way to get that information out, it's not like it was a document he just didn't give us, right? It was knowledge and it was in his head. So, we actually came up with a creative solution for that. Whereas during training, he could call and have a conversation like he was a customer. But if the agent ever went and did something he didn't want it to, and you know, it answered a question the way it didn't want he didn't want it to. And we actually built in kind of like a a keyword he could say, which would take the agent out of "I'm a rental agent solving your problems" into "I'm just listening now to how you want me to behave." And that would give that would give him the ability to dictate to it what exactly he would say. Right? Right? So now this is how I would handle the solution or the situation in in uh in that scenario. And then we would get that notes and our development team could incorporate that back into the behavior. Maybe that was changing the prompt, right? Maybe it was, you know, we were getting pricing wrong or uh it had read into something from the data and that that happened a few times like uh, you know, he doesn't rent painting equipment, doesn't rent paint sprayers or any of those things, but one of the descriptions of a different piece of equipment, I think it was a pressure washer, had something that confused the agent, right? So, he started asking questions and, you know, kind of broke in and said, "Wait a minute, I don't rent this stuff. How are you getting that?" So we had to figure out from what the model was responding with from our our our rag database as to what it was getting and why it thought that it rented something it didn't. And that allowed us to kind of correct the behavior and get back on on track. So that was a bit of an innovative thing that we built into the process for him in order to make it easy for him to to help us train.

How does this integrate into his existing business and um the stack?

Yeah. So, a little bit of challenges around that just because the software that he was on from a call it a back-end product doesn't expose a lot. So, we originally just gave him a very clean way to then take the the rental information that the c the customer wanted and input it. That was the first kind of phase. The second phase is to integrate with QuickBooks for him because that's what he uses in the background and they've got a more robust API. Uh so, we're going to leverage that for a lot of the things that we can then pull from an inventory perspective and data and customer information. So that's where we're pulling customer information and um updating customer information. We're leveraging QuickBooks from that perspective because his other tool didn't have it and he already has a synchronization between those two.

Yeah.

Was there any skepticism on his part about the potential for AI and agents to um kind of replicate him before you began and like how how does he feel about it now?

Yeah, there's definitely some skepticism because he's he's again he's a very vibrant individual, right? He's always he's outgoing. He's very engaging, right? So, he he wanted to really have a digital twin of himself and we didn't set out to digitize his personality, right? What we what we wanted to do was create something that could offload the work and do it in a very professional way and not sound, you know, like a robot to attend customers. So the the voice that we chose right from an engagement perspective was part of that the speed with which it talks and some of the the the ways it is engag is in some of that. So he was a bit skeptical at first partly because you know he is who he is from a personality perspective but also we just we had to temper that a little bit and say like that we're not trying to recreate you from a personality perspective. We're trying to recreate what you're doing in your business. Um so we set expectations a little bit from that perspective. Uh, and then once we got the first kind of MVP up and he could have a bit of a conversation, just ask questions about equipment, um, he was actually pleasantly surprised because it's just knowledgeable knowledgeable about what he has and um, what it could be used for and and whatnot. Um, and then we had to iterate and fine-tune on the various permutations and combinations of equipment, right, to to make it feel more like he would naturally engage. But once we got it to that level, I think uh, you know, it got him to a point where he was confident it could at least engage uh and and take a a good portion of of calls and answer, you know, a lot of questions that people had. Of course, we still need to give the customers a way that they can escalate. He can talk to them individually and answer questions if if the agent can't get it. And we anticipate that also improving over time, right? Give it a year worth of training and and back and forth and it'll be better than it is on launch.

Yeah. And my understanding this is recently deployed. So not all the numbers are in, but previously he was spending all his time doing customer service related calls. What does the kind of after state look like in terms of what his week is like now?

Yeah, you're you're right. We're we're early days. Um, it's kind of a phased roll out. So it's not it's not being asked to take 100% of his workload in the beginning here. So before any deployment, he was yeah on the phone all the time. probably 70% of his day was on the phone either answering questions or taking new bookings or dealing with an issue of of a rental. So the out of the gate numbers were we're anticipating tracking that towards 50% of his calls which mainly is going to be the bookings and pricing inquiries and do you rent this equipment or that equipment. We fully anticipate that he's still going to handle customer issues where they've had a problem, the machine can't start, they had an accident, right? those types of scenarios, we fully anticipate him still engaging and that's where he's going to spend his time on the phone. But those low hanging fruit from a from a customer inquiry or booking, we anticipate taking those calls. So, probably about half of his total calls.

Yeah. And 70% of his time was on call. So, you're talking about potentially freeing up 35% of his time.

Yep.

And tell me a little bit about the role of the managed service part of the business here. um what what what what are you doing with him on an ongoing basis to ensure this works and scales and delivers that value?

Yeah. So, as part of the ongoing service, so first of all, we give him visibility into what's going on. So, we have a a portal that has access into view all the calls. It analyzes sentiment of the call. So, he he can flag up if there was a call that was a negative sentiment. you can follow up with the customer if need be or he can listen to the call or read the transcript and then give us feedback and say, "Hey, this is this is behavior we need to correct." So the service is really to provide him the visibility into what's going on and then work with him to correct anything where the behavior isn't what he wants. So then he gets the product that he wants long term, right? In addition to that kind of visibility and ability to see what the agent's doing, that human oversight, we also have some effort for him to tune it. So, for example, you know, dispatching is something he he thinks it might do in the future. Well, if if that dispatch is as simple as saying, "Hey, this order is in and we can read his backend financial system and it's due out tomorrow, right? At the end of the day, the agent could go through all of the things that are due to be delivered tomorrow and it could go and and make a phone call or a text message to the drivers to go and say, "Hey, here's your your schedule for the day." So building those additional functionalities in over time is another element of the the managed service too. So it's going to continue to grow and add value to his business.

And this was a voice agent. Tell me a little bit more about voice agents and why is voice such an important domain for AI right now.

Yeah, I think I think voice is one of the things that we've you know we think we've built a really good product around and we're a little bit surprised to see how quickly that part of the industry's taken off. There's there's tons of new development coming out from Frontier Models and and other companies that are focused on making voice better, you know, and and that's great because we can take advantage of that, right? Our platform is going to be able to take advantage of new technology under the hood to to make it better in the future. So, that's fantastic for us. We welcome that. So, I think the advancements that are coming in in the voice space and the um ability to expand that into other areas like I mentioned marketing earlier, right? outbound marketing could be an area you could expand voice into. So, we're excited about all all that that's going on. I think the other thing that's interesting from a voice perspective is, you know, the way that the way that people work is going to change. I think it already is, right? You see uh large investments in in different modes of of technology like glasses, right? Instead of sitting at a computer and typing and moving a mouse like we've done for decades, right? um you know, mobile and dictation of things to your phone and having glasses that could recognize the environment and then interact with you through voice and having that backed up by a large language model and a voice agent. You know, all of those things coming together uh I think is where the the future of voice is going. I think that's kind of exciting.

Yeah. Uh this example is for rental services company. What other types of companies or industries could this type of solution be valuable for? Also, I mean, I think the voice agent, think about what this this is doing is really order taking. So, any type of interaction where you've got a product catalog and pricing and your customers call in or potentially just want to have a more robust conversation with you over an agent on your website that can actually take action. I think this is applicable. Right? So that's a pretty wide swap just in what we've already got um that we've talked about today. Right? Uh the the other thing though that I think is interesting about the platform and where Agentic AI is going is um you know it's it's adaptable to many different business processes. So we're we're looking at um like a sales coaching agent. Again, it's going to ingest voice. It's going to ingest calls from sales calls. Uh, it's going to give feedback on products that they could offer as part of the customer's needs. It's going to analyze what they're doing for their customers today and and where they could fill the need of their customers in the future. It's going to help them do research on new people they're meeting in order to see what their priorities might might mean or might be. So, you know, there's a there's that compostability, that expandability of the platform, I think is pretty exciting, too. So, you know, anything from a and that's not really just voice, that's voice, that's text, that's, you know, just regular search, all that coming together in in another agentic in aentic way.

Yeah. Very cool.

As we come to a close, um would love your advice for SMB leaders. So, what's a piece of advice for a leader who's skeptical about whether there are opportunities within his or her business to use AI?

Yeah, I I think for an SMB leader who's maybe hesitant, I think educating yourself on what's going on a little bit. I mean, obviously I'm deep in the weeds every day in this space. Um, and and it's impossible for someone who's running a business to get that deep into it that's not doing it for their business. But take the time. Take the time to educate yourself. Start using it. even if it's just, you know, asking questions about what your industry is doing or trends or how how you could look at a problem a different way. I think once once people start interacting with AI in a in a general sense and thinking about it in their business, the light bulbs will start to go off and and then they'll investigate further. And then I think once they get to that point, having conversations with companies like ours, right? To just talk about the art of the possible is is a really good way to explore what potentially you could do, right? Doesn't cost you anything to have a conversation with a company and say, "Hey, what do you do and how would it work in my business?" But I think once once the light bulb goes off and they see the potential, that's, you know, that's going to be it's going to be a phase shift for their business. And I don't I don't want to sound like fear-mongering or or anything else, but I also do firmly believe that if you're burying your head in the sand right now, like if you're just like it's not applicable, I run a small business. It's chat's bit just for big enterprise. Why would I bother? Or it's not real. It's all hype, right? I think that's probably the worst decision, right? Because I I do firmly believe that it's going to change, you know, the way people work, the way businesses are built, right? the way that your competition is operating. So, if you just choose to ignore it, you you truly do run the risk that someone's just going to just bypass you, right? Either a new company that's starting up in your space that's going to embrace it from the ground or one of your competitors that's that's taking advantage to educate themselves and reaching out to companies and having conversations and looking for use cases, right? I mean, if you're going to hire one new person, maybe take that investment and do something in the AI space. see if that can return more than what one new person would do in your organization.

Right. So, I think just getting started is the most critical thing. Yeah. Awesome. What a good place to end. Len, I really appreciate you coming by just curious and sharing more about what you're doing with Helios Core and how you're helping small businesses use this technology to better navigate the future. Thank you. Thanks, D. Really appreciate it. Can't wait to uh talk to you about more use cases in the future.
